data.name: Home_Organisation_Involvement_Text
data.value:
Over time several people have contributed in various roles.

  • Discussion partners: Bas Savenije, Saskia de Vries, Sijbolt Noorda, Marc Dupuis, Margreet Bouma, Natalia Grygierczyk, Wim Liebrand, Astrid van Wesenbeeck, Henk Wals, Wijnandt Mijnhardt, Maurits van der Graaf.
  • Funding contributions: SURF, NWO, CWTS, KNAW, Radboud University.
  • Prototyping the Editorial Board Indicator: Paul Wouters, Rodrigo Costas.
  • Developing the Journal Score Card: Jelte Wicherts.
  • Testers of the Transparancy Indicator (predecessor of the Journal Score Card): Leon Osinski (TU Eindhoven), Birte Kristiansen (Leiden University), Wouter Gerritsma (Wageningen UR), Teunis van Lopik (National Library), Gemma Indemans (Radboud University), Thijs Severens (Radboud University), D. Jonkheer (Radboud University), Erika Manten (Utrecht University), Jaap de Lange (TU Delft), Eric Rumondor(TU Delft), Astrid van Wesenbeeck (National Library), Leen Seekles (National Library), Jorden Esser (TU Delft), Corry Stuyts (Tilburg University), Marike van Dorsser (Radboud University), Marijke van der Ploeg (Tilburg University), Saskia de Vries, Saskia Franken (Utrecht University), Saskia van Putten (Radboud University), Leo Waaijers.
  • Co-organizers of the Rotterdam colloquium: Saskia de Vries, Marc Dupuis, Annemiek van der Kuil, Tom Olijhoek.
  • Attendees of the Rotterdam Colloquium: Celina Ramjoue (European Commission), Robert Kiley (Wellcome Trust), Franciska de Jong (Netherlands Organisation for Scientific Research), Falk Reckling (Austrian Science Fund), Paul Boyle (Science Europe), Peder Andersen (Ministry of Science, Innovation and Higher Education), Hans Bennis (Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences), Deborah Kahn (BioMedCentral), Martin Rasmussen (Copernicus), Wim van der Stelt (Springer), Paul Peters (Hindawi), Cameron Neylon (PloS), James Butcher (Nature Publishing Group), Frank van Laerhoven (International Journal of the Commons), Leonie de Goei (BMGN - Low Countries Historical Review), Aad Blok (International Review of Social History), Marcel Hommel (Malaria Journal), Jacintha Ellers (Journal of Insect Physiology), Mark van Loosdrecht (Water Research), Jack Middelburg (Biogeosciences), Jeffrey Beall (Predatory journals), Lars Bjørnshauge (SPARC Europe), Jan Velterop (Aqnowledge), Martin Enserink (Freelance journalist (Science)), Jelte Wicherts (Tilburg University), Paul Wouters (CWTS, Leiden University), Saskia de Vries (Co-organiser), Tom Olijhoek (Co-organiser), Marc Dupuis (SURF), Leo Waaijers.
  • Developers QOAM web site: Erik Schierboom, Maurice Vanderfeesten, Marlon van Haren.
  • Federated authentication for the Netherlands academic community: Pim Slot
  • Licencing OA deals for the Dutch Universities: Pim Slot
  • Supervisor: Leo Waaijers.

data.name: Home_Faq_Framing_Text
data.value:
To avoid unqualified contributions to QOAM, only members of the academic community may publish Journal Score Cards. Membership will be controlled by federated authentication via trusted third parties like SURFconext in the Netherlands. Per person only one JSC may be published for a specific journal. Published Journal Score Cards are non-anonymous. Their authors can be contacted by other members of the academic community via the Profiles section of QOAM.
Currently, QOAM has no resources to organise any form of social control or moderation. We have to rely on academic vigilance. Jeffrey Beall’s list of predatory journals and John Bohannon’s article Who is Afraid of Peer Review? are examples of this.

data.name: Home_Faq_Framing_Title
data.value: Is QOAM prone to improper use?

data.name: Home_Faq_HybridJournalsIncluded_Text
data.value:
Author centric, QOAM provides all journals that offer open access publishing. This entails hybrid journals. Some hybrid journals manage to generate a double income by charging both readers (via full library subscriptions) and authors (via full publication fees).
The initiators of QOAM despise this ‘double dipping’ but QOAM is not the instrument to combat this directly. However, if institutions succeed in negotiating journal licenses that end these practices, the license results and more specifically their effect on the publication fees will be mentioned on QOAM’s web site (be it that in most cases one has to log in with their institutional account to see if this applies to one’s institute). For example, SURFmarket succeeded to settle such deals with SAGE and the Royal Society of Chemistry on behalf of UKB, the Dutch consortium of university libraries and the National Library.

data.name: Home_Faq_HybridJournalsIncluded_Title
data.value: Why are hybrid journals also included in QOAM?

data.name: Home_Faq_NoMetrics_Text
data.value: Metrics for QOAM must apply to young journals because most journals which are born OA are in their infancy. Therefore, the Journal Impact Factor is not included. The Leiden institute CWTS developed an Editorial Board Indicator, a metric for the scientific impact of the editorial board. The main obstacle for applying it is the problem of identifying the board members; just a name and an affiliation are not enough for that. The importance of having a clear identification of the Editorial Board members of scientific journals (i.e. their full names, affiliations, e-mail and even their ORCID identifier) can be also considered as an element of transparency and quality. Should these data be more transparent and accessible, indicators on the scientific impact of the editorial board could then be extensively developed and included in QOAM. See SURF. Other straightforward young journal metrics would be welcomed by QOAM as well.

data.name: Home_Faq_NoMetrics_Title
data.value: Why does QOAM not include metrics as a quality proxy?

data.name: Home_Organisation_Text
data.value: In its operational stage QOAM must be run by an independent robust service provider. SURFmarket, already the licensee for the national package deals with the subscription publishers, has shown an interest to operate it. The organisation of QOAM is under construction.

data.name: Home_JournalScoreCard_ShowIt_Title
data.value: Show it!

data.name: Home_JournalScoreCard_WhatIsJournalScoreCard_Text
data.value: A Journal Score Card (JSC) is a questionnaire on five relevant journal aspects. Four of them – Editorial information, Peer review, Governance and Process - are based on the journal’s website. The fifth – Valuation – is a reality check, preferably based on experience with the submission of an article to the journal. Every aspect has some bullets and each bullet can be rated from 1 to 5. The average of these ratings is called the subscore for this aspect. The lowest subscore of the four web site related aspects is called the Base Score of the journal. The subscore of the fifth aspect is called the Valuation Score of the jounal.

data.name: Home_JournalScoreCard_WhatIsJournalScoreCard_Title
data.value: What is a Journal Score Card?

data.name: Home_About_BriefHistory_Text
data.value:
For long, SURF has been convinced that in the OA paradigm, next to price quality is a critical issue. For established journals the Journal Impact Factor, though controversial, is used as a proxy for quality but for young journals there is no such quality indicator whatsoever. This is a specific handicap for young OA journals whereas young subscription journals are often just included in Big Deal packages. The outcomes of the EC-project SOAP confirmed a growing urgency to address the quality issue for OA journals (later alarmingly demonstrated by the emergence of predatory journals and John Bohannon’s article Who is Afraid of Peer Review?)

As early as 2009 SURF took the initiative to investigate the feasibility of an accreditation system for young OA journals. The idea was embraced by the European Commission but rejected by SURF’s OpenAIRE project partners (who stuck to the Green Road to OA). Publishers and funders reacted expectantly. SURF left this approach after all and, in hindsight, it might have been too ambitious.

In autumn 2011 a new endeavour was started, this time aiming at tools that would enable a crowd sourced solution. For that purpose two indicators were prototyped: an Editorial Board Indicator, a metric for the scientific impact of the editorial board, and a Transparency Indicator, checking the transparency of the article admission process. Both indicators were presented, and the second one even tested, at an international expert colloquium in Rotterdam, October 2012.

The main obstacle for the first indicator was, and still is, the problem of identifying the board members; just a name and an affiliation are not enough for that. (See FAQ “Why does QOAM not include metrics as a quality proxy?”) The second indicator turned out to be more readily applicable as was demonstrated by the test in Rotterdam and subsequently by a group of Dutch university libraries. These encouraging results led to the development of the more comprehensive Journal Score Card as a first measure of young journal quality.

data.name: Home_About_BriefHistory_Title
data.value: A brief history

data.name: Home_About_EinsteinRazor_Text
data.value: Overall, the builders have tried to apply Einstein’s razor: “Make web sites as simple as possible, but not simpler.”

data.name: Home_About_EinsteinRazor_Title
data.value: Einstein’s razor

data.name: Home_About_FilteringPerDiscipline_Text
data.value: QOAM allows filtering per discipline. Thus the varied recognition of the different aspects over the disciplines can be taken into account. E.g. if speed of publication is less important in a specific discipline all journals in this discipline will produce a low subscore for the aspect ‘process’, which might be their Base Score. As in QOAM journals are ranked by default according to their Base score, a general search would result in a place at the bottom of the list for this journals. Within their own discipline the other aspects are more profiling.

data.name: Home_About_FilteringPerDiscipline_Title
data.value: Filtering per discipline

data.name: Home_About_JournalScoreCards_Text
data.value:
In QOAM quality of a journal is determined by the academic community itself via so called Journal Score Cards. A Journal Score Card is a questionnaire resulting in subscores for five critical aspects of a journal. Four of them – Editorial information, Peer review, Governance and Process - are based on the journal’s website. The fifth – Valuation – is a reality check, preferably based on experience with the submission of an article to the journal. The lowest subscore of the four web site related aspects is called the Base Score of the journal. The subscore of the fifth aspect is called the Valuation score of the jounal.

QOAM offers members of the academic community the opportunity to publish a Journal Score Card for one or more of the OA and hybrid journals in QOAM’s scoring section. (NB This section includes all DOAJ journals.) Although there may be afterthoughts about hybrid journals (see FAQ “Why are so called hybrid journals also included in QOAM?”), from an author-centric point of view they may simply be prestigious journals in which one can publish articles in open access as well. (Read more about Journal Score Card)

data.name: Home_About_JournalScoreCards_Title
data.value: Journal Score Cards

data.name: Home_About_PriceInformation_Text
data.value:
For standard price information QOAM links directly to the website of a journal. However, a growing number of institutions, and more specifically their libraries, succeed in negotiating better prices for their community via memberships, licences or other agreements. Unfortunately, publishers often include non-disclosure clauses in their contracts. Therefore, prices may not always be referred to directly on the QOAM website, but per journal QOAM will list the licensed institutes. Searching authors can see if their institute is on the list. In that case they can log in to their own institutional intranet and compare the institutional price to the standard price.

Currently, prices vary widely. According to Peter Suber the vast majority of peer-reviewed OA journals are no-fee. Journals that do charge have an average price of €700 per article, but price quotations may mount to €3000 and up. In such a bewildering situation sharing price experiences might give some guidance. For that reason a question is included in the Valuation aspect asking for the actual publication price of a published article. The replies are shown in reverse chronological order behind the tab Price information next to the standard price and the institutional price.

data.name: Home_About_PriceInformation_Title
data.value: Price information

data.name: Home_About_QualityOfService_Text
data.value: When scientific and scholarly publishing is no longer seen as copyright exploitation but as a service, as is the case in the OA paradigm, there is a need for a market where quality of the service can be matched against price. So, once the Journal Score Card was developed (see A brief history below) it was a natural step to create a place where information about actual journal prices, that is publication fees, was available as well. The idea of the Quality Open Access Market – QOAM - was born. As QOAM will be operating in a nascent market, both its journal quality indicator and the information about pricing are in their infancy and may need further development. But one has to start somewhere.

data.name: Home_About_QualityOfService_Title
data.value: QOAM – quality of service matched against price

data.name: Home_About_ForWhom_Text
data.value:
First and for all, QOAM aims at authors who want to publish their article in open access in a high quality journal and for a reasonable price. Then there is the library community. In the subscription period libraries were invaluable to academia when building up high quality collections. The Big Deals with their take-it-or-leave-it approach seemed to make this capacity redundant. QOAM enables libraries to apply this competence anew in the open access world by publishing Journal Score Cards and give journals feedback on how to improve. Last but not least, QOAM makes the world of academic publishing transparent to policy makers, journalists, and the public at large.
Therefore, QOAM is a public website. But academics have to log in with their institutional account for publishing a Journal Score Card (to avoid misuse) or if they want to check if their institution has bargained a good publication price (because of non-disclosure clauses of publishers).

data.name: Home_About_ForWhom_Title
data.value: For whom is QOAM useful?

data.name: Home_About_Why_Text
data.value:
Recently, Science Europe’s Position Statement has reconfirmed the Open Access imperative.

“Research publications are one of the main results of the research process and the Research Performing and Research Funding Organisations that comprise Science Europe share the vision of increasing the impact and reducing the costs of research publications by moving to a system of Open Access.”

reads their statement, and also

“The Science Europe Member Organisations [..] require that as part of the publication services provided against the payment of Open Access publication fees, effective mechanisms are in place to ensure that the publication of research outputs is subject to rigorous quality assurance.”

data.name: Home_About_Why_Title
data.value: Why?

data.name: Home_Faq_CantFindJournal_Text
data.value:
A. in QOAM’s searching section?

The reason is that for this journal a Journal Score Card has not been published yet. To remedy this, go to the “I want to publish a Journal Score Card” section on QOAM’s main page and publish a JSC for the journal in question. Alternatively, ask your library to do so.

B. in QOAM’s scoring section?

We suggest to ask your library for advice. They know how to have a journal added to databases that underly QOAM and/or how to migrate a journal from there to QOAM. Once done the journal will pop up in QOAM (provided it is an OA or hybrid journal).

    QOAM’s scoring section   QOAM’s searching section
Underlying external databases » OA and hybrid journals in QOAM » Journal Score Cards in QOAM
  The composition of QOAM

data.name: Home_Faq_CantFindJournal_Title
data.value: Why don’t I find a specific journal in QOAM?

data.name: Journals_Prices_IPaid
data.value: I paid

data.name: Home_JournalScoreCard_WhoMayPublish_Title
data.value: Who may publish JSCs in QOAM?

data.name: Home_JournalScoreCard_HowAreJournalScoreCardsUsed_Text
data.value:
In QOAM journals are ranked by default in order of their Base Score. So, a journal at the top of the list, i.e. with a high Base Score, has a web site that addresses all the journal aspects adequately. On the other hand, a journal with a low Base Score has at least one weak aspect, but may still be strong in other respects. In order to climb on the list a journal must address its weakest aspect.

Next to the Base score the Valuation score of a journal is shown. This score reflects an appraisal of the journal, preferably based on a real submission. If this experience is lacking, circumstantial information may do and a free text box gives room for additional comments. NB Price information is only asked for when it is based on submission experience. In QOAM it is possible to limit a search to submission based Journal Score Cards only.

QOAM has the option to filter journals per title key word, ISSN, publisher, discipline and language. Filtering per discipline enables to take the varied recognition of different aspects over disciplines into account. E.g. if speed of publication is less important in a specific discipline all journals in this discipline will produce a low subscore for the aspect ‘process’, which might be their Base Score. In a general search this would result in a place at the bottom of the ranking. Within their own discipline the other aspects are more profiling.

On top of that, every academic author can decide for herself which aspects she deems most relevant. Per journal all aspect subscores are produced.

data.name: Home_JournalScoreCard_HowAreJournalScoreCardsUsed_Title
data.value: How are JSCs used in QOAM?

data.name: Home_JournalScoreCard_WhoMayPublish_Text
data.value:
Members of the academic community with a Higher Education (HE) institutional account can select open access and hybrid journals from QOAM’s scoring section. (See the FAQ “Why are so called hybrid journals also included in QOAM?”) Then QOAM offers the opportunity to publish a Journal Score Card for one or more of the selected journals. Per person only one JSC may be published for a specific journal. In case several people publish a JSC for the same journal the averaged subscores will be attributed to the journal. Thus QOAM is crowd sourced in a controlled way.

Every JSC is presented in QOAM for a period of a year. Authors can edit their published JSC at any moment, e.g. in order to reflect new developments of the journal. Updated Journal Score Cards will be dealt with as newly published ones. Thus QOAM is kept up to date.

A year after its publication a JSC expires and will be archived. It no longer plays a role in QOAM but its author will keep access to it via the Profile section of QOAM. A month before a JSC will be archived its author will be notified of the upcoming expiration and will be invited to update their JSC (provided they are still a member of the academic community.) Thus QOAM keeps in touch with people who committed themselves by publishing a JSC.

The Journal Score Card as a format will be evaluated periodically and possibly adapted to new insights. However, changes will not be abrupt and draft versions will be circulated for comment prior to installation. As JSCs are archived after a year the migration period in which ‘old’ and ‘new’ subscores sit together lasts a year at most. Effectively the migration period could be shorter because everybody may edit their JSC any time. Thus, the JSC evolves organically.

data.name: Journals_Index_ReadMorePriceInformation
data.value: Read more about Price information.

data.name: Home_Faq_CantFindJournal_Title_Short
data.value: Why don’t I find a specific journal

data.name: Journals_Scores_OnlyMembersPublish
data.value: Only members of the academic community may publish a JSC. See FAQ "Is QOAM prone to improper use?"

data.name: Profiles_Details_NoScoreCards
data.value: {0} has not yet published any Journal Score Cards.

data.name: Profiles_Details_YouMayContact
data.value: You may contact {0} if you are logged in

data.name: Home_Faq_SubscriptionJournalsNotIncluded_Text
data.value:
QOAM is in the overlap of three domains: (1) Quality, (2) Open Access, (3) Market. Do subscription journals fit into these domains?
Ad 1. Quality. Yes. The Journal Score Card is business model neutral.
Ad 2. Open Access. No. Subscription is at odds with Open Access.
Ad 3. Market. No. The current Big Deal packages obscure any market idea.
So, subscription journals do not fit in QOAM. Yet, the initiators of QOAM are convinced that quality control as such is equally well necessary for subscription journals. Especially for new journals which are simply included in existing packages. The Journal Score Card, or an adapted version of it, might be applicable here and the initiators of QOAM are open to discuss this.
